Yes, I definitely believe that AR and VR will become more common in special education classrooms in the future. As the technology continues to evolve, it is becoming more accessible and affordable, making it easier for schools to integrate these technologies into their classrooms and provide unique learning experiences for students with disabilities.

Additionally, research has shown that AR and VR can have a positive impact on students with different abilities, especially those with learning difficulties or physical disabilities. This has led to increased interest among educators and schools to explore the use of these technologies in their teaching practices.

Moreover, with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, there has been a growing interest in virtual learning environments and the potential of AR and VR technologies to support remote learning for students with disabilities.

In conclusion, as the benefits of AR and VR in special education become more recognized, it is likely that we will see more of these technologies being used in classrooms to enhance the learning experiences of students with disabilities.
